5-Year Accident History:
There have been no RMP-applicable accidental releases at the facility within the last five years where exposure to propane, overpressure generated by an explosion involving propane, or radiant heat generated by a fire involving propane has led to any death, injury, or response/restoration activities for an exposure of an environmental or public receptor.

Contractors:
The objective of the Contractor Safety program is to ensure that all contractors working at the USEN site are properly qualified, understand potential hazards of the Aerosol Recycling Unit and the site in general, are trained in the site's safe work practices, and are informed about the site-specific Emergency Contingency Plan. The procedures apply to all non-USE workers required to perform physical work within the facilities operation boundaries. The safety records and practices of all contractors are assessed prior to work on the ARU. Contractors are mandated to various trainings on the above topics.

Trade Secrets:
The facility is diligent in its development of all documentation relating to processes covered by the CAPP/RMP/PSM programs. Therefore, information necessary for the development, implementation, and integration of the safety programs are provided to those involved in the program regardless of trade secret status.

Emergency Response Plan:
In accordance with 40 CFR Part 265 Subpart D, US Ecology Nevada maintains and strictly follows an Emergency Contingency Plan containing all elements mandated by 40 CFR 265.52. This plan is developed and annually reviewed under the direction of the facility Health and Safety Manager and further designates Emergency Coordinators (EC). Employees will immediately notify the EC upon identifying a fire, explosion or release of hazardous waste or constituents which could threaten human health or the environment.

Pre-Startup Safety Review:
The purpose of the Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) Procedure is to ensure the completeness, operability, and safety of the Aerosol Recycling Operation. The PSSR Procedure will assure that appropriate safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place, and will verify that process hazard analysis (PHA) and management of change (MOC) have been performed as required by regulation. The PSSR will be implemented prior to the initial startup of the Aerosol Recycling Operation, and thereafter if required by MOC.

Compliance Audits:
The Compliance Audit includes reviews/inspections of existing documentation, policies and procedures, and supporting records to determine the quality of program implementation for the facility. Personnel interviews are performed, as necessary, to assist in verifying that documentation and records provided are accurate and to demonstrate the awareness and participation of the facility’s personnel.

Incident Investigation:
The USEN Accident & Incident Investigation Program exists to outline the procedures required for reporting, documenting, and investigating incidents. Emphasis is placed on determining cause and ensuring prevention against reoccurrence.

Employee Participation:
The Employee Participation Program defines the different mechanisms available to employees to assist in all health and safety programs at the Beatty Facility. Site employees play a critical part in identifying risks as well as system improvement across the entire facility. The program applies to all employees at the facility, and all employees are strongly encouraged to participate through the site’s employee health and safety recognition program.

Operating Procedures:
The Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and Safe Work Practices (SWPs) for the US Ecology Nevada CAPP/RMP/PSM covered-processes are developed with strict adherence to SOPs and SWPs recommended by OEM manual and applicable codes. SOPs contain sections of safety and health considerations, special or unique hazards. They also refer to the SDS sheets for more information and control measures to be taken if exposure occurs. They also detail the PPE required to prevent exposure. SOPs also include sections for safety systems and their functions, and, in some cases, quality control of raw materials.

Training:
Specific training for personnel involved in the operation of the ARU/Tank Farm has been developed in the Aerosol Recycling Operation Training Program. This is additional to the general Personnel Training Program. The team determines all appropriate training subjects have been identified and appropriate training methods have been developed by interviewing personnel and reviewing training methods applied for gaps in understanding.

Mechanical Integrity:
The USEN Mechanical Integrity Program validates PSI and applies it to the implementation of a robust program of preventative maintenance. Tasks, and frequencies are based on vendor manuals and applicable codes and standards. When the equipment does not have a vendor O&M manual, the PMs have been developed based on recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices (RAGAGEP) and/or facility experience. Preventative maintenance and corrective maintenance activities are scheduled, tracked, and documented.

Management of Change:
The purpose of this procedure is to ensure that changes in operating practices, facility changes, new or modified equipment, process changes or new processes do not introduce an unrecognized or unacceptable hazard, or compromise the safeguards built into the Aerosol Recycling Operation. Hazard Assessment:
The facility models worst-case and alternative-case scenarios in the context of propane. This information is kept internally.

Process Safety Information:
The facility ensures that Process Safety Information (PSI) pertaining to the hazards of the highly hazardous chemical (propane) and its related process conforms to all applicable codes, standards, and good engineering practices. The team works together to ensure PSI is kept current and made available to all personnel. This includes technology of the process and the equipment in the process (SDS, Process Flow Diagrams, EOM manuals, relief design information, process chemistry, and equipment OEMs, including permissible flows and operating limits).

Process Hazard Analysis:
The Process Hazard Analysis is an organized and systematic assessment of the potential hazards associated with an industrial process. This is accomplished through methodologies including Hazard and Operability Study, What-if, Checklists, or a combination of these. The PHA considers hazards of the process; any previous incident that had a likely potential for catastrophic consequences, including, without limitation, near misses or accidental releases; engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards and their interrelationships such as appropriate application of detection methodologies to provide early warning of releases; consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls; facility siting; human factors; external forces; and a qualitative evaluation of a range of the possible safety and health effects of failure of controls on employees in the workplace. Recommendations are tracked in a PHA recommendation log and the recommendations are shared with the employees affected by the recommendation as part of scheduled training in the Training Program. The Aerosol Recycling Unit’s CAPP/RMP/PSM Chemical Accident Prevention Program – which comprises 15 elements including an Emergency Action Plan and regularly scheduled Process Hazard Analyses – is an important component of that ongoing commitment to a comprehensive system of safety onsite. 

To prevent accidental chemical releases of propane that could result from administrative failure or improperly assigned responsibility at the Aerosol Recycling Unit, US Ecology Nevada’s Prevention Program was developed around a foundational Management System (or “implementation plan”) which establishes a clear system of organization, responsibility, operating procedures, process safety information, hazard identification, and document control. The implementation plan covers each element of the prevention program and the emergency response program and defines how each requirement of each such element will be implemented at the facility. 

While the facility’s General Manager has ultimate responsibility for the program, US Ecology Nevada has created a collaborative team charged with the development, implementation, integration, and consistent review of each program component. Team members – in continuous consultation with each other and the General Manager – take ownership of the management of specific elements based on subject matter expertise and administrative experience. For most elements, both primary and secondary responsibility is assigned in order to ensure that no principle execution is overlooked or missed.

US Ecology Nevada Executive Summary:
Propane Utilized in the Aerosol Recycling Unit

US Ecology Nevada (USEN) is a hazardous waste disposal facility located remotely in the Amargosa Desert in Nye County, Nevada. The Facility is located on a 480-acre site, which is leased from the State of Nevada. The nearest resident is approximately 11 miles away in Beatty, Nevada, the closest town. USEN utilizes about 160 acres for active operations, which include the treatment, storage and disposal of hazardous wastes regulated by both the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) and the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA). Additionally, USEN operates an aerosol can recycling process. The Aerosol Recycling Unit (ARU) processes collected aerosol cans by separating the contents from the metal in a crusher, and isolating out the propellant, which is a flammable mixture consisting primarily of propane. The propane is then stored in tanks for beneficial re-use. 

The Aerosol Recycling Unit, its storage tank farm, and all interconnected piping are processes covered by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s Risk Management Program rule (RMP), OSHA’s Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, and the State of Nevada’s Chemical Accident Prevention Program (CAPP). The threshold quantity for propane in all programs is 10,000 lbs.; the maximum intended inventory of propane at the USEN Aerosol Recycling Unit is 32,000. 

Protecting the safety of people, the community and the environment is a core value of the company; the facility is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and in its dedication to the practices that keep its employees and the neighboring communities safe. In December 2023, the facility was recognized by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) as a “Star” worksite within OSHA’s Voluntary Protection Program (VPP).
